Imports the `fetch_openml` function from the `sklearn.datasets` module. `fetch_openml` allows the user to bring in the datasets available in the OpenML platform. Every dataset has a unique ID, hence, can be fetched by providing the ID. `data_id` of the French motor dataset is 41214. 3. If it already exists, then read the dataset as a `.csv` file ::: ## Data dictionary {.smaller} ::: columns ::: column - `IDpol`: policy number (unique identifier) - `ClaimNb`: number of claims on the given policy - `Exposure`: total exposure in yearly units - `Area`: area code (categorical, ordinal) - `VehPower`: power of the car (categorical, ordinal) - `VehAge`: age of the car in years - `DrivAge`: age of the (most common) driver in years ::: ::: column - `BonusMalus`: bonus-malus level between 50 and 230 (with reference level 100) - `VehBrand`: car brand (categorical, nominal) - `VehGas`: diesel or regular fuel car (binary) - `Density`: density of inhabitants per km^2^ in the city of the living place of the driver - `Region`: regions in France (prior to 2016) ::: ::: ::: footer Source: Nell et al. (2020), [Case Study: French Motor Third-Party Liability Claims](https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3164764), SSRN. ::: ## The model Have $\{ (\mathbf{x}_i, y_i) \}_{i=1, \dots, n}$ for $\mathbf{x}_i \in \mathbb{R}^{47}$ and $y_i \in \mathbb{N}_0$. Assume the distribution $$ Y_i \sim \mathsf{Poisson}(\lambda(\mathbf{x}_i)) $$ We have $\mathbb{E} Y_i = \lambda(\mathbf{x}_i)$. The NN takes $\mathbf{x}_i$ & predicts $\mathbb{E} Y_i$. # Ordinal Variables {visibility="uncounted"} ## Subsample and split ::: {.cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} freq = freq.drop("IDpol", axis=1).head(25_000) #<1> X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split( #<2> freq.drop("ClaimNb", axis=1), freq["ClaimNb"], random_state=2023) #<2> # Reset each index to start at 0 again. X_train = X_train.reset_index(drop=True) #<3> X_test = X_test.reset_index(drop=True) #<3> ``` ::: ::: {.content-visible unless-format="revealjs"} 1. Drops the `"IDpol"` column and selects only the top 25_000 rows of the dataset 2. Splits the dataset in to train and test sets. By setting the `random_state` to a specific number, we ensure the consistency in the train-test split. `freq.drop("ClaimNb", axis=1)` removes the "ClaimNb" column. 3. Resets the index of train set, and drops the previous index column. Since the index column will get shuffled during the train-test split, we may want to reset the index to start from 0 again. ::: ## What values do we see in the data? ::: {layout-ncol=2 layout-nrow=2} ::: {.cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} X_train["Area"].value_counts() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=15} ``` Area C 5507 D 4113 A 3527 E 2769 B 2359 F 475 Name: count, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} X_train["VehBrand"].value_counts() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=16} ``` VehBrand B1 5069 B2 4838 B12 3708 ... B13 336 B11 284 B14 136 Name: count, Length: 11, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} X_train["VehGas"].value_counts() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=17} ``` VehGas 'Regular' 10773 'Diesel' 7977 Name: count, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=18} ``` {.python .cell-code} X_train["Region"].value_counts() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=18} ``` Region R24 6498 R82 2119 R11 1909 ... R21 90 R42 55 R43 26 Name: count, Length: 22, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.content-visible unless-format="revealjs"} `data["column_name"].value_counts()` function provides counts of each category for a categorical variable. In this dataset, variables `Area` and `VehGas` are assumed to have natural orderings whereas `VehBrand` and `Region` are not considered to have such natural orderings. Therefore, the two sets of categorical variables will have to be treated differently. ::: ## Ordinal & binary categories are easy ::: {.cell execution_count=19} ``` {.python .cell-code} from sklearn.preprocessing import OrdinalEncoder #<1> oe = OrdinalEncoder() #<2> oe.fit(X_train[["Area", "VehGas"]]) #<3> oe.categories_ #<4> ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=19} ``` [array(['A', 'B', 'C', 'D', 'E', 'F'], dtype=object), array(["'Diesel'", "'Regular'"], dtype=object)] ``` ::: ::: ::: {.content-visible unless-format="revealjs"} `OrdinalEncoder` can assign numerical values to each category of the ordinal variable. The nice thing about `OrdinalEncoder` is that it can preserve the information about ordinal relationships in the data. Furthermore, this encoding is more efficient in terms of memory usage. 1. Imports the `OrdinalEncoder` from `sklearn.preprocessing` library 2. Defines the `OrdinalEncoder` object as `oe` 3. Selects the two columns with ordinal variables from `X_train` and fits the ordinal encoder 4. Gives out the number of unique categories in each ordinal variable ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=20} ``` {.python .cell-code} for i, area in enumerate(oe.categories_[0]): print(f"The Area value {area} gets turned into {i}.") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` The Area value A gets turned into 0. The Area value B gets turned into 1. The Area value C gets turned into 2. The Area value D gets turned into 3. The Area value E gets turned into 4. The Area value F gets turned into 5. ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} for i, gas in enumerate(oe.categories_[1]): print(f"The VehGas value {gas} gets turned into {i}.") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` The VehGas value 'Diesel' gets turned into 0. The VehGas value 'Regular' gets turned into 1. ``` ::: ::: ## Ordinal encoded values ::: {.content-visible unless-format="revealjs"} Note that fitting an ordinal encoder (`oe.fit`) only establishes the mapping between numerical values and ordinal variable levels. To actually convert the values in the ordinal columns, we must also apply the `oe.transform` function. Following lines of code shows how we consistently apply the transform function to both train and test sets. To avoid inconsistencies in encoding, we use `oe.fit` function only to the train set. ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=22} ``` {.python .cell-code} X_train_ord = oe.transform(X_train[["Area", "VehGas"]]) X_test_ord = oe.transform(X_test[["Area", "VehGas"]]) ``` ::: ::: columns ::: column ::: {.cell execution_count=23} ``` {.python .cell-code} X_train[["Area", "VehGas"]].head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=23} ```{=html}

Sets the random state for reproducibility 2. Constructs a neural network with 1 `Dense` layer, 1 neuron and an exponential activation function 3. Compiles the model by defining the optimizer and loss function 4. Defines the early stopping object (Note that the early stopping object only works if we have a validation set. If we do not define a validation set, there will be no validation loss, hence, no metric to compare the training loss with.) 5. Fits the model only with the encoded columns as input data. The command `validation_split=0.2` tells the neural network to treat the last 20% of input data as the validation set. This is an alternative way of defining the validation set. 6. Returns the validation loss at the final epoch of training :::
What about adding the continuous variables back in? Use a sklearn _column transformer_ for that. ## Preprocess ordinal & continuous ::: {.cell execution_count=26} ``` {.python .cell-code} from sklearn.compose import make_column_transformer #<1> ct = make_column_transformer( #<2> (OrdinalEncoder(), ["Area", "VehGas"]), #<3> ("drop", ["VehBrand", "Region"]), #<4> remainder=StandardScaler() #<5> ) X_train_ct = ct.fit_transform(X_train) #<6> ``` ::: ::: {.content-visible unless-format="revealjs"} 1. Imports the `make_column_transformer` class that can carry out data preparation selectively 2. Starts defining the column transformer object 3. Selects the ordinal columns and apply ordinal encoding 4. Drops the nominal columns 5. Applies `StandardScaler` transformation to the remaining numerical columns 6.
